newsitem.title: USA: US adj retail sales up 2.3 pct w/e June 7-Redbook.
newsitem.headline: US adj retail sales up 2.3 pct w/e June 7-Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 2.3 percent in the first week of fiscal June versus May, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook Retail Sales Index.

The index rose 8.8 percent compared to the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales also climbed 8.8 percent in the week ended June 7, compared with the same week a year ago, it said.
Retailers noted a pickup in business nationwide, as the long-awaited warmer weather attracted consumers towards seasonal goods, said Howard Eilenberg, a retail analyst at Redbook Research.
"Discounters finally came around and sold (goods) that was on the shelves since early in the season," said Eilenberg in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
"(The customers) had the money, and they were waiting to buy... until the need arose," he said.
Eilenberg said retail activity should pick up for the rest of June, citing benign weather and comparisons against softer sales registered in June 1996.
"The comparisons against a year ago are rather easy," the Redbook Research analyst said, adding that shoppers, for many reasons, refrained from buying apparel goods last June.

The spending power that was held back in April and May, coupled with the easy year-ago comparisons, should boost sales in June, Eilenberg said. As a result, retailers may not have to adjust their sales plans as they had anticipated, he said.
"The markdowns won't be as steep as (retailers) thought, and therefore, they can make some money at it," Eilenberg added.
